image.altText: A woman in a red sweater looks at the camera as she leaves a court building followed by a man and another woman

items.synopsis: A couple found guilty of the 2009 murder of their ex-son-in-law will appeal the verdict on a number of grounds, claiming the judge "erred in fact or law" — and that two jurors in a "pre-existing relationship" were not dismissed.

title.children: Convicted murderer couple to appeal guilty verdict over killing of ex-son-in-law

image.altText: Australia's women's 4x100m medley relay team hug after the Commonwealth Games final.

items.synopsis: Victorian Premier Daniel Andrews confirms the state will no longer host the 2026 Commonwealth Games due to cost blowouts. Follow live.

title.children: Commonwealth Games bodies slam Victorian government's decision to walk away from hosting duties

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese was a little hesitant to say too much about the Games cancellation, preferring to focus on events that were actually going ahead. "That's a decision made by the Victorian government. I'll leave the Victorian government to go through those details," he said of the news this morning. "But I'm certainly focused on a sporting event that will happen in two days time with the Matildas and I think that the whole of Australia will be cheering them on, with the opportunity that we have of hosting the World Cup here." "The World Cup is the third largest sporting event held in the world, only beaten by the men's football World Cup and the Olympic Games. And we're hosting it, we're hosting the Olympics in south-east Queensland, of course, in 2032. And Australia has a fine record of hosting events."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Anthony Albanese responds to Games cancellation

children.content: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese was a little hesitant to say too much about the Games cancellation, preferring to focus on events that were actually going ahead.
"That's a decision made by the Victorian government. I'll leave the Victorian government to go through those details," he said of the news this morning.

"But I'm certainly focused on a sporting event that will happen in two days time with the Matildas and I think that the whole of Australia will be cheering them on, with the opportunity that we have of hosting the World Cup here."

"The World Cup is the third largest sporting event held in the world, only beaten by the men's football World Cup and the Olympic Games. And we're hosting it, we're hosting the Olympics in south-east Queensland, of course, in 2032.
And Australia has a fine record of hosting events."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The premier has been asked why the Games couldn't have been held in Melbourne, rather than cancelled altogether? He says the government has "looked at every option". "We have looked at every conceivable option. All of them are far in excess of the $2.6 billion that's been budgeted, so all of them represent more cost than there is benefit, and on that basis none of those options stack up and we're not going to be hosting the Games in 2026." He said many of Melbourne's competition-grade facilities were "fairly busy". "So there is a cost so we would not be using them, and there is also the small matter of you could save money by not building villages for instance, but then every hotel room in the city would be pretty much taken up by those who are part of the Games, not those who are coming here to watch the Games. "So again the cost-benefit ratio does not stack up."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: So why not just move the Games to Melbourne?

children.content: The premier has been asked why the Games couldn't have been held in Melbourne, rather than cancelled altogether?
He says the government has "looked at every option".

"We have looked at every conceivable option. All of them are far in excess of the $2.6 billion that's been budgeted, so all of them represent more cost than there is benefit, and on that basis none of those options stack up and we're not going to be hosting the Games in 2026."
He said many of Melbourne's competition-grade facilities were "fairly busy".

"So there is a cost so we would not be using them, and there is also the small matter of you could save money by not building villages for instance, but then every hotel room in the city would be pretty much taken up by those who are part of the Games, not those who are coming here to watch the Games.
"So again the cost-benefit ratio does not stack up."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The government is committed to improving sporting facilities across regional Victoria and says the planned upgrades that were to accompany the Games will still go ahead. That includes upgrading Eureka Stadium in Ballarat to seat 10,000 spectators and upgrades to Bendigo Stadium.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Regional sporting facilities to be upgraded

children.content: The government is committed to improving sporting facilities across regional Victoria and says the planned upgrades that were to accompany the Games will still go ahead.
That includes upgrading Eureka Stadium in Ballarat to seat 10,000 spectators and upgrades to Bendigo Stadium.

image.altText: Lara Alexander, John Tucker and Jeremy Rockliff.

items.synopsis: It was inevitable Tasmanian Premier Jeremy Rockliff would rule out forcing local councils to amalgamate: the Liberals are in minority, the party faithful in the regions are grumpy and Labor are weaponising the issue, writes Laura Beavis.

title.children: Tasmanian Liberals baulk at forcing council mergers in order to survive

image.altText: Flowers of the tea tree plant.

items.synopsis: Mild temperatures in July are tricking some plants into budding — and that'll be bad when the frost returns.

title.children: Warmer winter has flowers blooming early — and that isn't good

image.altText: Storm clouds gather over the ocean at dusk.

items.synopsis: The BOM has held off on declaring El Niño yet again, despite most other international agencies having already made the call. So why are we at odds with the rest of the world?

title.children: What's it going to take for Australia to declare El Niño?

image.altText: Greg Craven

items.synopsis: A constitutional lawyer who supports the Voice to Parliament says he is likely to complain to the electoral commission, after being quoted in official material for the No case.

title.children: Pro-Voice to Parliament lawyer quoted in official No pamphlet furious at inclusion

image.altText: A man in a suit sits at a bench with his head down, flagged by a man and woman in business attire, inside a committee room.

image.altText: A close-up man wearing a white shirt

image.altText: A pile of broken down Barbie dolls.

items.synopsis: Toys are the most plastic-intensive consumer goods in the world. So how can we avoid movie tie-in fads adding to the surging plastic waste problem, asks Alan Pears.

title.children: After the Barbie movie frenzy fades, how do we avoid tonnes of Barbie dolls going to landfill?

image.altText: A photo of a toddler with blonde hair and blue eyes looking into the camera.

title.children: Man found guilty of 2019 murder of toddler Jaidyn Gomes-Sebastiao

image.altText: A buckled and damaged bridge

items.synopsis: The day started with two mysterious explosions on Putin's beloved Kerch bridge and ended with Russia withdrawing from a crucial deal to allow Ukrainian grain to pass through the Black Sea. Here's everything we know.

title.children: A furious Putin, a busted bridge and a torn-up deal: Russia and Ukraine's wild 24 hours explained

image.altText: The Sierra Leone-flagged cargo ship, Razoni carrying Ukrainian grain leaves the port, in Odesa

items.synopsis: Food prices spiked after Russia invaded Ukraine, but the Black Sea export deal helped to stabilise them. Now the deal's off, and analysts are warning of a price "roller-coaster".

title.children: What now for global food prices after Russia pulls pin on Black Sea grain deal?

image.altText: Farm workers picking fruit in the field.

items.synopsis: Linx Employment is under investigation as seasonal workers in Queensland allege they have not been given adequate hours and have been left homeless, without enough money to return home.

title.children: Labour hire company under investigation for alleged 'bullying', mistreatment of Pacific workers

image.altText: A man in a fishing shirt and hat stands on a beach

items.synopsis: It's not yet clear whether the dingoes involved in the latest attack that took place on K'gari will the euthanased.

title.children: Reports dingoes becoming more brazen, as fate of animals involved in attack on jogger hangs in the balance

image.altText: Close up of person with long hair with head bent and two hands covering their face, leaning on their forehead.

items.synopsis: Prolonged, lower-level stressors at work can combine to have a significant mental health impact. But it's not up to the individual to address the problem.

title.children: Sophie loved her job, until it made her so anxious she had to quit. She's far from alone

image.altText: A mobile phone is held in a person's hand at the ASX in Sydney

items.synopsis: The ASX dropped after minutes from the Reserve Bank revealed it may raise interest rates again because of high inflation.  Look back at how the day unfolded on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: RBA keeps door open to more rate hikes, ASX loses ground, EY boss paid $2.8 million — as it happened

image.altText: A composite image of Jim Chalmers and Philip Lowe.

items.synopsis: The Reserve Bank left interest rates on hold this month on fears that another rise could trigger a spike in unemployment, as the outgoing governor calls for politicians to tackle difficult productivity reforms.

title.children: 'Still risks everywhere': RBA left rates on hold amid fears of an unemployment spike

image.altText: a group of people walking in a busy city centre

items.synopsis: The world's second largest economy grew at a 6.3 per cent annual pace in the April-June quarter, much slower than the 7 per cent plus growth forecast.

title.children: China's economy misses growth forecasts, signalling slow recovery

image.altText: A footballer smiles while holding her baby daughter.

items.synopsis: Katrina Gorry reflects on her rollercoaster relationship with football, and how making the decision to become a solo parent helped her fall back in love with football.

title.children: 'I don't even feel like the same person': Matildas star opens up on how motherhood changed her approach to football

image.altText: A woman in a puffer jacket.

items.synopsis: Looking forward to a 12-day, world-class sporting event outside metro Melbourne, regional hosts say today's shock call by the Andrews Government is a "kick in the guts".

title.children: Regional Commonwealth Games host cities 'gutted' by cancellation

image.altText: daniel andrews tours ballarat's eureka stadium at announcement of 2026 commonwealth games

items.synopsis: The Andrews government has scrapped the regional Victorian Commonwealth Games, just 15 months on from announcing it would serve as the 2026 host.

title.children: Commonwealth Games cancelled in Victoria as government shrinks from $7b price tag

title.children: Engineer says space junk washed up on WA beach could be a 20-year-old Indian rocket

image.altText: Brain scans showing amyloid in Alzheimer's disease, with the shape of a head filled in with colour representing scan results

items.synopsis: Decades of research on Alzheimer's disease have started to come to fruition, with at least three new drugs demonstrating the first glimmers of promise.

title.children: Controversy over Dark Emu took a heavy toll on author Bruce Pascoe

image.altText: Landscape picture of red Kimberley hills and green valleys at sunset

title.children: Indigenous groups take majority ownership of $3b green export project in Australian first

image.altText: picture of a sign saying 'supreme court'.

items.synopsis: A convicted paedophile is eligible for parole a year earlier, after a NSW appeals court finds the sentencing judge failed to account for the impact of COVID on his custodial imprisonment.
